WRITING.TEXT:
Not as crazy as making a two-minute trailer for a 30-second film.
Suddenly I feel a project coming on . . .
Pretty cool and a great first attempt. If you want to add a bit of virtuosity, consider also animating the flames' reflection in the table.

"OCD" - I couldn't agree more. His process is downright bizarre! And I found that fascinating. It made me go back and listen to so many other Weezer songs in a new way, wondering about the real meaning and process behind them. I'm certainly not going to start cataloging phrases in a spreadsheet by number of syllables and stress, but the entire podcast was so eye-opening as to all of the possibilities. I found it really thought provoking.

It's not an exact match, but if you listen to a bunch of Song Exploder podcasts you pick up a lot about how the industry works for artists at varying levels of prominence. For example, the Metallica Song Exploder feels a lot different than the Perfume Genius one.

This is really worth a listen, showing the mental gymnastics and daily disciplines required for Rivers Cuomo to keep writing music that feels fresh for him. It shows me there aren't really any rules--each songwriter has to figure out what works for him or her to wrestle that muse out of the mind and get songs made.

WRITING.TITLE: On Song Exploder, Weezer's Rivers Cuomo reveals a songwriting process that's backward from anything I might have guessed

WRITING.TEXT: But now that you mention, he's worth a good listen (plus, someone I've met from my hometown). His track 1976, from Since We Last Spoke, is absolutely perfect. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lp-xN-o6W90
You should listen to DJ Shadow Entroducing like ten times. That album was so ahead of its time. It basically defined a genre.

WRITING.TITLE: "Difficult, difficult, lemon difficult" - from "In the Loop", one of the best cringe comedy moments of last decade

WRITING.TEXT:
Nice job. I'm wondering if you're a fan of DJ Shadow or Moby. I detect influences of both.
Keep at it. As you mentioned, the length is probably a slight problem if you want your music to be digestible and heard. Finding the editor within ourselves is one of the hardest parts of being an artist.
